Refrigeration plays an important role at CalChef Foods Facilities as it is necessary for safeguarding the products we handle.  CalChef recently leased  the site and has made improvements and  has reconfigured  the facility. The existing system was shut down and ammonia was removed from the refrigeration system in May of 2023.  The total amount of  ammonia (8,984 pounds) was pumped out.  New equipment was added and some existing equipment was capped off and other existing equipment is being re-used in the new configuration of the system with new operating conditions. Building Permits were approved for the new design and the system was brought up to the current 2022 California Building, Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing, Energy, and Green  codes.    At minimum, this design meets and often exceeds all applicable federal, state, and local codes and standards. The system start up is  planned for February 2024.

 At both the corporate and local levels, CalChef Foods. has taken significant steps to ensure safety both for its workers at the site and for the community at large. CalChef has implemented strict standards in the development and design of the process and both the building itself and the addition, and has overlaid administrative controls for operating, testing, inspecting, and maintaining the facility.

DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY
The facility is located at 3735 Imperial Way, Stockton CA.  It is within the Arch Road Industrial Park, just Northeast of the intersection of Arch Road and California Highway 99.

The Arch Road Industrial Park contains many other facilities of equal and larger sizes.

It is a modern, updated, 160,000 square foot  production and distribution center for the making of Kevin's Natural Food frozen products.

The overall facility site is an expanding industrial area, there are no hospitals or nursing homes within a one mile radius.  

The amount of ammonia in the system will exceed the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds so is required to follow th

e Federal EPA requirements for  a RMP regulated substance and the Federal OSHA PSM requirement, along with California State CalARP requirements.

Accident prevention is a high priority with CalChef Foods.  CalChef Foods. has corporate-wide goals, and procedures in place, to correct conditions that could lead to an accident.  The company takes numerous steps to prevent accidents and injuries, including the following: 

Develops programs to provide and maintain safe work environments

Provides employee training emphasizing safe work practices and potential on-the-job hazards

Performs periodic reviews of accident prevention programs and accident data to ensure that safe work practices are being followed

Provides incentive programs to promote safety awareness and interest among employees

All of these programs and provisions foster employee safety and awareness of potential hazards at each site.  Provisions are also in place for employees to report accidents or conditions that could lead to an accident. Any personnel injury accidents that do occur are reported in accordance with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) requirements. 

The California Health and Safety Code requires that an RMP include a description of each "accident" involving the acutely hazardous material for which the RMP is being prepared that has occurred at the business or facility within the last three years of operation.  The description is to include identification of underlying causes of the accident and the measures taken, if any, to avoid a recurrence of a similar accident. 

DEFINITIONS OF "ACCIDENT" AND FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

The term "accident" (as it relates to an RMP) is defined in Section 25532 (b) of the California Health and Safety Code.  The Health and Safety Code uses the term "accident risk" to broaden the definition of accidents to include potential accidents or near misses.  The definition for accident is as follows: 

"... a potential for the release of an AH

M into the environment which could produce a significant likelihood that persons exposed may suffer acute health effects resulting in significant injury or death."

Depending on the specific type of industry or process being evaluated, the definition of "accident" can vary significantly.  For instance, while the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) refers to "accidents" as incidents that involve worker injury, and does not specifically relate to release of hazardous material, Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (SARA) Title lll defines specific federal reporting requirements for releases of hazardous material.  The SARA standards establish chemical-specific criteria for reporting releases based on the quantity of material released over a specified duration.  For example, any release of ammonia that exceeds 100 pounds in 24 hours must be reported under SARA Title lll requirements.  Unlike the OSHA standard, the SARA reporting requirements are independent of worker injury. 


Due to this is a new facility and owner there are no accidents to report.

SYSTEM DESCRIPTION (Anhydrous Ammonia System)
Anhydrous Ammonia is the chemical used in the refrigeration system in this facility.  Refrigeration systems of this type are the most widely used in the world, primarily due to their reliability, safety and cost.  These systems are inherently safe and are designed and installed with automatic, computer-controlled monitoring systems to both indicate necessary maintenance procedures and sound the alarm in case of accident.  Ammonia is a lighter-than-air gas at atmospheric pressure and temperature and would rise quickly and disperse if released into the environment.  The primary hazard associated with ammonia is acute toxicity when inhaled or ingested. Ammonia also poses a hazard when coming into contact with the skin.

PRINCIPLES OF AMMONIA REFRIGERATION
"Refrigeration" is a general term used to describe the cooling of a space or substance to a te

mperature below the ambient temperature.  Mechanical refrigeration is an application of thermodynamics wherein a cooling medium, or "refrigerant," goes through a sequence of phase changes, the net effect of which is to absorb heat from one location and transfer it to another.  This process occurs in a closed cycle so that the refrigerant is recycled.  In the CalChef Foods. facility at the Stockton site, ammonia is the refrigerant.  In the ammonia refrigeration cycle, liquid ammonia expands, absorbs heat from the surroundings, ammonia vapor is compressed, condensed to a liquid, and then expanded.  As it expands, ammonia liquid changes back to vapor and absorbs heat from its surroundings, thereby providing refrigeration.  After absorbing heat, the vapor is compressed again, repeating the cycle. 


Most larger industrial systems rely on ammonia as a refrigerant.  Ammonia was chosen as the at the CalChef Foods. Stockton site for many of the same reasons it has been selected by other manufacturers:

     1. Ammonia is a highly efficient refrigerant.
     2. Ammonia does not have any ozone depletion potential.
     3. Ammonia does not have any global warming potential. 
     4. Although ammonia, like several other refrigerants, has toxic properties, it
          has many advantages over other refrigerants in terms of worker and 
          community safety:
 
Ammonia is easily detected by smell in concentrations well below levels that could be harmful. 
Ammonia gas is lighter than air and will rise and disperse into the atmosphere if released.  
Ammonia has a high affinity for absorption in water.  This increases the effectiveness of emergency response actions.


**Equipment and Operation
The ammonia refrigeration facility in Stockton is based on a standardized, risk-preventing design. 

The ammonia refrigeration facility at the Stockton site is new or recent construction, built to meet, and in many instances exceed, industry standards such as 2021 IIAR-2 and ASHRAE-15 (se

e Glossary), and other documents including the most recent California Building Code (CBC), California Fire Code (CFC), and the California Mechanical Code (CMC).  All new equipment, including piping, vessels, valves, instrumentation, and controls  are state-of the-art engineering design and construction.  The equipment is subject to inspections during construction and installation to ensure compliance with design and construction standards. 

 Wherever possible, ammonia piping connections are of welded construction. Welded construction provides the strongest, most leak-proof type of piping connection.  Flanged and possibly screwed connections are used for specialty equipment that cannot be welded, such as system relief valves.

The equipment for the refrigeration system is located in the following  areas: the Engine Room, the prep room, packaging room, production room, WIP room and freezer storage, LPR room, dock, spiral freezer, or mounted on the building roof-top.

a)Screw Compressors
These transform cold, low pressure ammonia gas into hot, high pressure gas. This transformation is accomplished using single-stage screw compressors with two suction levels and a high level used for cooling the compressors.

b)Condensers
These transform hot, high pressure ammonia gas into hot, high pressure liquid
. 
c) Expansion Valves
These allow liquid ammonia to expand from high pressure to low pressure.  This causes the ammonia temperature to drop so that it can absorb heat.  The expansion valves also regulate refrigerant flow through the cycle.  Standard expansion valves act as the barrier between the high and low pressure parts of the refrigeration cycle. 

d) High Pressure Receivers
These receive and store ammonia in its liquid form.  These pressure rated vessels are designed, built, and inspected according to ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers) standards.  The receivers have the capacity to temporarily store a majority of the ammonia used in the system.  Periodica

lly, the receivers are used to store ammonia to allow maintenance or inspection of other system components.  After passing through the ammonia receivers, ammonia liquid flows to the expansion control valves for each chiller.

e) Recirculators
These vessels, with ammonia pumps, supply liquid ammonia to the air handlers and receive the return suction for passage to the screw compressors.

f)Oil Pot Draining
Oil pots on the large recirculators are used to collect any oil accumulation.  This excess oil is drained as part of the routine periodic maintenance of the system.

g) Ammonia Charging
Ammonia is charged into the system through a charging valve located on the receiver vessel.

h) Air Handlers
These fan units operate in the cool rooms and freezer.  They are mounted near the ceiling and provide cooling by blowing air across cold, low pressure ammonia lines from the recirculators.

i) Auto-Purger
This device separates air and non-condensable gases from the ammonia, dilutes them with water, and disposes of them

2.  Detection, Monitoring, Automatic Control Systems, and Procedures
CalChef Foods. ammonia refrigeration facility is a state-of-the-art design with highly sophisticated monitoring and control capabilities.  Every part of the design and operation of the facility is geared to prevent accidents and to safely contain ammonia within the system.  This is accomplished through the use of design features that provide automatic system shutdown if critical parameters are beyond the normal operating conditions, local as well as remote monitoring of system operation, and numerous system controls and interlocks that alert the operator of any problems and enable the operator to shut the system down if necessary. 

For example, one unique accident prevention feature inherent in the ammonia refrigeration facility is that very little human interaction is required.  The refrigeration process involves recirculation of ammonia and, other than periodic system monitoring, there is

virtually no need for operator involvement in the normal operation of the system, thus reducing potential risk of human error. 

In the unlikely event that a problem occurs that results in release of ammonia from the refrigeration system, a sophisticated ammonia detection system located throughout the ammonia refrigeration facility will sense the presence of ammonia, provide an audible alarm, and initiate safety systems and system shutdown if required.

AMMONIA LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM AND REFRIGERATION SYSTEM AUTOMATIC CONTROLS 

One of the single most important properties of ammonia from a safety perspective is its strong, pungent odor. Ammonia can be sensed by the human nose in concentrations as low 50 parts per million (ppm) in air. This odor threshold concentration of ammonia is well below the levels that pose a health hazard. Therefore, the odor of ammonia provides an early warning signal that allows people to evacuate contaminated areas and take protective actions long before significant hazards exist. 

Additionally, CalChef Foods.' ammonia refrigeration facility includes a sophisticated ammonia leak detection system that automatically initiates safety systems as well as local and site alarms.  The sensing system will be capable of detecting ammonia at concentrations as low as 25 parts per million.  It is important, however, to assure that the alarms and the responses to them are commensurate with the severity of the problem.  For example, it would not be appropriate to evacuate the site for a small ammonia leak that would not be harmful.  Likewise, large leaks would require a greater level of response and initiation of precautionary actions.  For this reason, the ammonia detection system will have different responses for varying levels of detected ammonia concentration.  These responses will initiate a local alarm at 25 ppm.

An Emergency Pressure Control System (EPCS) has been installed that has a high pressure switch set at 90% or less of the associated reli

ef valve set point. Upon activation the compressors are shut down and a solenoid valve opens and equalizes the overpressure.  In this system the ammonia is kept in the piping and valves prior to the relief valve lifting to atmosphere.

In addition to the automatic controls associated with the ammonia leak sensing system, there will also be automatic controls associated with operation of the refrigeration compressors.  Each of the compressor units is controlled by a microprocessor.  Among its other functions, the microprocessor operates a series of interlocks which, in the event that pre-established critical parameters are exceeded, shut down the compressor.  As an additional safeguard, auxiliary system controls also exist to shut off the compressors if certain critical parameters for auxiliary equipment are exceeded. 

AMMONIA REFRIGERATION FACILITY OPERATING PARAMETER MONITORING.

Ammonia Leak Detection System Automatic Controls
AMMONIA CONCENTRATION (Parts per million - ppm). EQUIPMENT RESPONSE
25 ppm (in the building) Triggers blue strobe activation for local notification.
35 ppm (in the building) Triggers red and blue strobe and send a supervisory signal
45 PPM Triggers a red and blue strobe and sends a general alarm, activates the exhaust fans and a signal is sent to the Monitoring company from the Fire/Ammonia Control Panel that then contacts the fire department as needed.

As discussed previously, the ammonia refrigeration system is a closed-loop, recirculating process, with little or no need for operator involvement.  Under normal conditions, the operator's primary role is to monitor process instrumentation, providing information regarding process parameters such as pressure and temperature.  Under normal operating conditions, these process parameters do not vary to any significant degree.  Deviations from normal operation are therefore easily detected. 

The operator also conducts periodic inspections of the system to visually inspect primary system compone

nts, record critical process parameters, and note any abnormal conditions in the facility (leaks, excessive equipment vibration, etc.). These walkdowns are performed at least once every 24 hours.   

Because of the fully automatic nature of the system, the elaborate alarm system, and the limited need for operator involvement in the normal operation of an ammonia refrigeration system, there is no need for an operator to be present continuously in the ammonia refrigeration building.  This system includes a computer-based system that continuously monitors important system parameters and checks the status of the ammonia sensing system.  In the event that a critical process parameter deviates from normal range or a leak detector reaches an alarm setpoint, personnel at the remote monitoring location are alerted to take necessary corrective action.  The remote monitoring station for Stockton's refrigeration facility is installed in a central monitoring area in the Maintenance Department.  Security personnel can provide a secondary level of notification to contact appropriate CalChef. individuals to respond to an incident.  
 

Process Hazards Analysis

During the  Engineering Design Phase (development of specifications and system design), CalChef,  conducts a Process Hazards Analysis.  This analysis uses a systematic and comprehensive method to ensure that the finished design provides for safe and orderly construction, startup, operation, maintenance, and shutdown of the facility.  This review also includes a follow-up on the open issues identified in the Preliminary Safety Review.  The results of the Process Hazards Analysis address the following points:

     1) Analysis of Process Hazards:
          a. Installation (facility)
          b. Routine operation (process)
          c. Non-routine operation (startup, shutdown, maintenance)
          d.  Emergency situations
          e. Human factors
          f. Facility siting's
          g. Impact to the environment

h. Site Specific and Industry Incidents


     2) Follow-up on open issues from previous review(s)

The technique  used for the Process Hazards Analysis is a What if Checklist


Pre-Startup Review

Upon completion of construction, immediately prior to startup and before the introduction of chemicals or raw materials into the process, we conduct a Pre-Startup Review.  The purpose of this final review is to ensure that all safety items from previous reviews have in fact been incorporated into the actual construction, and that the process and facility can be safely started and operated.  This review also follows up on the results of the Preliminary Safety Review, the Process Hazards Analysis and the Layout Safety Review.  The Pre-startup Safety Review is usually done using a checklist. 

An actual walkthrough inspection of the process facility takes place after the team completes the checklist.  Any problems or exceptions are recorded and a judgment is made by the safety team as to whether a safe startup can take place.  Items identified as impacting a safe startup must be resolved before startup take place.  Startup cannot take place until the safety team concurs that a safe startup (and emergency shutdown, if necessary) can take place.  The project is not "closed" until all action items have been resolved.  The Pre-startup Safety Review addresses the following points: 

     1) Walkthrough inspection of facility
     2) Establishment of ability to safely start the process
     3) Establishment of ability to safely shut down the process
     4) Verification that the process and facility can be safely operated and
          occupied
     5) Verification of completeness of training
     6) Follow-up on open issues from previous reviews
     7) Review of process safety information

 Administrative Operating Control
Operation of the ammonia refrigeration facility is a straightforward process that requires very little operator interaction.  The system functions as a clo

sed recirculating loop.  The operators perform system inspections, maintenance activities, and periodic testing of components.  The following controls have been incorporated into the standard operating procedures that apply to the Stockton site:

Operating procedures for the system are available in writing, in an easily followed format. 
The procedures include directions for system startup, shutdown, interruptions, and emergency situations.  There also is a written emergency evacuation procedure and equipment lockout/tagout procedure. 
Mechanisms are in place to ensure operating procedures, Piping and Instrumentation Drawings (P&IDs), and equipment, instrumentation and piping inspection lists are kept up to date. 
Operating personnel have trained in system startup, shut down, troubleshooting and emergencies. 
A control room walkdown has been performed to verify operating procedures are accessible to operators for reference. 
Provisions are in place to have supervisory personnel check on operators on a regular basis. 

Delivery of ammonia will be required to initially "charge" the addition to the refrigeration system.  Also, in the future, it will be necessary to recharge (replacing only a portion of the charge) the refrigeration system with ammonia, similar to the recharging of an automobile air conditioner.  It is estimated from past experience that the system may need to be done every 2-3 years. 

At least two trained contractor technicians will be present at all times during the charge/recharge process.  Appropriate safety equipment and gear will be readily available and/or worn at all times during this process. 


Inspection Procedures and Schedules

CalChef. utilizes inspection procedures and schedules that have been developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration IIAR-6.   

 Maintenance Procedures and Schedules

During operation, inspections and monitoring of critical system parameters are performed routinely.  Preventive maintenance procedu

res are carried out by a contractor specializing in ammonia refrigeration systems. Using a schedule prescribed by IIAR-6 to ensure that all components are in their best possible condition.  Any deviations from normal operating parameters are observed and corrected. 

As required by the federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration (29 CFR Part 1910, February 24, 1992), a process safety management program has been established at this location to properly identify, evaluate and prevent chemical releases that could occur as a result of failure in process, procedures, or equipment.

The program is designed to provide reasonable assurance that operation hazards are identified, that significant operational safety incidents are avoided, that operational safety requirements are considered in evaluating business decisions and that unacceptable risks to persons, property, products, and the environment are avoided.

The process includes all phases of plant operations including conceptualization, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and decommissioning.

REQUIREMENTS:

Employee Participation - Develop written plan of action on employee participation; consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of process hazard analysis; and provide access to other information pertaining to process safety.

Training - Appropriate training in applicable tasks and procedures is provided to affected employees to enable them to perform their jobs safely and effectively under a variety of operating conditions.  For new employees, initial training includes verification that employees involved with a covered process have the required knowledge, skill, and abilities to safely perform their duties and responsibilities.  Written documentation of all training is maintained.

Incident Investigation - All process related incidents are reported in accordance with established policies governing actual or near-miss incidents.  The report is reviewed with all

affected personnel including contract employees.

Hot Work Permit - A hot work and/or other applicable permits are issued for work performed on or near a process involving highly hazardous chemicals.  Documentation addresses fire prevention and that fire protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the work operations.  The documentation indicates date(s) and identification of the object to be worked on or near.

Emergency Planning and Response - An Emergency Response Team (ERT) has been selected and trained as part of the Plant Emergency Organization (PEO).  The ERT will respond to releases of hazardous chemicals including small planned releases.

Operating Procedures - Written operating procedures have been developed which provide clear instructions for operating the process safely and communicate to affected employees.  Procedures include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems.  These procedures are readily accessible to employees and reviewed as often as necessary to assure they are current.

Mechanical Integrity - Testing and inspection procedures have been developed and implemented, which are consistent with applicable codes and good engineering practice, to provide reasonable assurance that the mechanical integrity of critical process equipment is maintained.  All equipment deficiencies are corrected before further use, or appropriate steps are taken in a timely manner to assure safe operation.

Contractors - Applies to contractors involved in maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process.  Consideration is given to a contractor's safety programs and performance prior to being awarded work on or near covered processes.  Contractors are informed of potential hazards, facility Plant Emergency Organization (PEO) plan, safe work practices in process areas, and their responsibility to maintain an injury/illness log.  Con

tractors are responsible for training their employees in safe work practices, documenting that training, and assuring that their employees know about potential process hazards (i.e. facility PEO and safety rules).  Contractors must also advise the site employer of hazards the contract work poses or hazards identified by contract employees.

Management of Change - A written procedure to manage changes to process chemicals, technology equipment, and procedures or changes to facilities that affect highly hazardous chemicals must be in place prior to implementation of the change, the impact of the change on safety and health, the modification to current operating procedures, time period for the change, and the authorization requirements for the change.  All the employees affected by the change are informed of and trained in the chance prior to start-up.

Pre-Start Up Safety Review - New facilities and modified sites of covered process perform a safety review prior to start up to insure that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications, all operating procedures are in place, and necessary employee training is complete.

Process Safety Information - Written information has been compiled for process involving highly hazardous chemicals to allow for a thorough process hazard analysis and the completion of other loss prevention activity.  This includes information on chemical hazards, process technology and equipment, design and operation specs.

Process Hazard Analysis - Processes have been assessed to identify, evaluate, and control potential hazards.  PHAA¿s have addressed the hazards of the process, previous hazardous incidents engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failures of engineering and administrative controls, human factors and evaluation of efforts of failure of controls on employees.

Compliance Audit - Audits are conducted at least every three years, and are conducted in appropriate intervals to ensure and asses the

programs implementation and effectiveness.  A report of the findings of the audit should determine and document that the deficiencies have been resolved or corrected.  The two most recent audits must be retained. This program is new so the 1st compliance audit will be completed 3 years from the date of submission.

Notwithstanding the low likelihood of such releases and the significant safety features that would mitigate an event that does occur, CalChef Foods will take the necessary steps to ensure that all elements of emergency response are developed to address potential releases of ammonia.
